used to emphasize that a particular person does something and that you believe other people do too

examples.text: I, for one, would prefer to postpone the meeting.

data.sense: to understand or guess something immediately

examples.text: ‘Oh, so she’s his sister!’ ‘Got it in one!’

data.sense: to get an advantage over somebody/something

examples.text: I'm not going to let them get one over on me!

data.sense: to do something better than somebody else or than you have done before

examples.text: She did well this year and next year she hopes to go one better.

data.sense: used to say that somebody/something has different roles, contains different things or is used for different purposes

examples.text: She's a mother and company director in one.
It's a public relations office, a press office and a private office all in one.

data.sense: first one person or thing, and then another, and then another, up to any number or amount

examples.text: The bills kept coming in, one after another.

data.sense: everyone

examples.text: Happy New Year to one and all!

data.sense: used to emphasize that somebody is famous

examples.text: Here she is, the one and only Rihanna!

data.sense: used for emphasis to mean ‘the same’

examples.text: I never realized Ruth Rendell and Barbara Vine were one and the same (= the same person using two different names).

data.sense: separately and in order

examples.text: I went through the items on the list one by one.

data.sense: a few

examples.text: We've had one or two problems—nothing serious.

data.sense: having an advantage over somebody

data.text: when you’ve seen, heard, etc. one, you’ve seen, heard, etc. them all
data.sense: used to say that all types of the things mentioned are very similar

examples.text: I don't like science fiction novels much. When you've read one, you've read them all.

data.text: the year one (North American English) (British English the year dot)
data.sense: a very long time ago

examples.text: I've been going there every summer since the year one.

note.text: For the special uses of off in phrasal verbs, look at the entries for the verbs. For example come off is in the phrasal verb section at come.

senses.text: used to say that something has been removed or become separated

examples.text: He's had his beard shaved off.
Take your coat off.
The label must have fallen off.
Don't leave the toothpaste with the top off.
The water is off.
Make sure the TV is off.
I called him but he ran off.
He fell off a ladder and broke his arm.
Sarah's off in India somewhere.
I must be off (= I must leave) soon.
Summer's not far off now.
A solution is still some way off.
Off you go! Enjoy yourselves!
She's off today.
I've got three days off next week.
How many days did you take off?
I need some time off.
They're off (= the race has begun).
shoes with $20 off
All shirts have/are 10 per cent off.
The wedding is off.
Sorry, the duck is off.

data.sense: to be in a better or worse situation

examples.text: She's better off without him.
The weather was so bad we'd have been better off staying at home.
We can't be any worse off than we are already.

data.sense: to have a particular amount of something

examples.text: How are we off for coffee (= how much do we have)?

data.sense: used to say how much money somebody has

examples.text: Families will be better off under the new law (= will have more money).
They are both comfortably off (= have enough money to be able to buy what they want without worrying too much about the cost).

data.sense: from time to time; now and again

examples.text: It rained on and off all day.

senses.text: used with be, do or have to form the negative of verbs; used to form the negative of modal verbs like can or must

examples.text: She did not/didn’t see him.
It’s not/It isn’t raining.
It's cold, isn't it?
Don't you eat meat?
I can't see from here.
He must not go.
He warned me not to be late.
I was sorry not to have seen them.
Not everybody agrees.
They had still not decided.
‘Who's next?’ ‘Not me.’
‘What did you do at school?’ ‘Not a lot.’
It's not easy being a parent (= it's difficult).
It's not every day you get to meet a famous actor.
‘Will she be there?’ ‘I hope not.’
‘Is it ready?’ ‘I'm afraid not.’
(formal) ‘Does he know?’ ‘I believe not.’
I don't know if he's telling the truth or not.
Whether you succeed or not depends on the how skilled you are.
‘Some more?’ ‘Not for me, thanks.’
‘Can I throw this out?’ ‘Certainly not.’
She was standing not three feet in front of me.
This could all happen in the not too distant future (= soon).
His view on the matter was not a million miles away from (= close to) mine.
Well, that sounds like a fun evening—not!

data.sense: used for emphasis to mean ‘no thing or person’

examples.text: He didn't speak to me—not one word.

data.sense: used to politely accept thanks or to agree to something

examples.text: ‘Thanks a lot.’ ‘Not at all.’
‘Will it bother you if I smoke?’ ‘Not at all.’

data.sense: used to emphasize that something else is also true

examples.text: She not only wrote the text but also selected the illustrations.
He not only read the book, but also remembered what he had read.

data.sense: used to state that you are not suggesting something

examples.text: She hasn't written—not that she said she would.

note.text: For the special uses of on in phrasal verbs, look at the entries for the verbs. For example turn on somebody is in the phrasal verb section at turn.

on May the first/the first of May

on your birthday

on the left/right

a town on the coast

senses.text: not anything; no single thing

examples.text: There was nothing in her bag.
There's nothing you can do to help.
The doctor said there was nothing wrong with me.
Nothing else matters to him apart from his job.
It cost us nothing to go in.
(British English) He's five foot nothing (= exactly five feet tall).
We did nothing at the weekend.
‘What's that in your pocket?’ ‘Oh, nothing.’
I know next to nothing (= almost nothing) about art.
She's always trying to get something for nothing.
All that preparation was for nothing because the visit was cancelled.
I'm quite a fast worker, but I've got nothing on her!
It looks nothing like a horse.
I had nothing like enough time to answer all the questions.

data.sense: to be a person for whom somebody has no feelings

examples.text: I used to love her but she's nothing to me any more.

data.text: be/have nothing to do with somebody/something
data.sense: to have no connection with somebody/something

examples.text: Get out! It's nothing to do with you (= you have no right to know about it).
That has nothing to do with what we're discussing.

data.sense: without paymentwith no reward or result

examples.text: She's always trying to get something for nothing.
All that preparation was for nothing because the visit was cancelled.

data.sense: to have much less of a particular quality than somebody/somethingto have no information that could show somebody to be guilty of something

examples.text: I'm quite a fast worker, but I've got nothing on her!

data.sense: used as a polite way of replying when somebody thanks you for doing something, to show that you were happy to do it

examples.text: ‘Thanks for all your help.’ ‘It was nothing—I enjoyed it.’

data.sense: for a very good reason

examples.text: Not for nothing was he called the king of rock and roll.

data.sense: only; no more/less than

examples.text: Nothing but a miracle can save her now.
I want nothing but the best for my children.

data.sense: extremely; very

examples.text: The trip was nothing if not varied.

data.sense: used to emphasize how great or extreme something is

examples.text: It was nothing less than a disaster.

data.sense: not at all likenot nearly; not at all

examples.text: It looks nothing like a horse.
I had nothing like enough time to answer all the questions.

data.sense: not a great amount of something; nothing of great value or importance

examples.text: There's nothing much in the fridge.
I got up late and did nothing much all day.

data.sense: (it’s) very easy

examples.text: You'll soon learn. There's nothing to it really.

data.sense: to be willing to do anything to get what you want, even if it is dishonest or wrong

examples.text: She’ll stop at nothing to make money.

data.sense: romantic words

examples.text: to whisper sweet nothings in somebody’s ear

data.text: there is/was nothing (else) for it (but to do something)
data.sense: there is no other action to take except the one mentioned

examples.text: There was nothing else for it but to resign.

data.sense: something is/was not true

examples.text: There was a rumour she was going to resign, but there was nothing in it.

data.sense: used to say that you enjoy something very much

examples.text: There's nothing like a brisk walk on a cold day!

senses.text: of a particular age

examples.text: be… years, months, etc. old The baby was only a few hours old.
In those days most people left school when they were only fifteen years old.
At thirty years old, he was already earning £40 000 a year.
two fourteen-year-old boys
a class for five-year-olds (= children who are five)
I didn't think she was old enough for the responsibility.
He's not too old to play Romeo.
How old is this building?
He's the oldest player in the team.
She's much older than me.
My two older sisters and I shared a bedroom.
He's old enough by now to manage his own affairs.
You are as old as you feel.
to get/grow old
The old man lay propped up on cushions.
a little old lady
She was a woman grown old before her time (= who looked older than she was).
He was beginning to look old.
Tom was the last surviving member of the older generation of the family.
She’s getting old—she’s 75 next year.
She is very busy caring for two elderly relatives.
Having aged relatives to stay in your house can be quite stressful.
Everyone in my family is exceptionally long-lived.
clothes for the mature woman
She was fairly old when she got married.
The way the young people rushed about made her feel old.
She's getting old—she's 75 next year.
We're all getting older.
The old feel the cold more than the young.
old habits

This carpet's getting pretty old now.
a beautiful old farmhouse
My brother is older than me.
The palace is the oldest building in the city.
my older/​elder sister
the elder/​older of their two children
I’m the eldest/​oldest in the family.
It's a very old tradition.
It's one of the oldest remaining parts of the church.
It's the world's oldest surviving ship.
These are some of the oldest trees in the world.
Things were different in the old days.
I went back to visit my old school.
Old and Middle English
People are still clinging to the old ways of thinking.
We had more room in our old house.
Mum and Dad bought us a fridge and gave us their old telly.
She's an old friend of mine (= I have known her for a long time).
We're old rivals.
It's always the same old faces.
The album includes both new titles and old favourites.
Good old Dad!
You poor old thing!
I hate her, the silly old cow!
It's a funny old world.
Why drink plain old water when you can have something better?

As my dear old Grandma used to say…

data.sense: any item of the type mentioned (used when it is not important which particular item is chosen)

examples.text: Any old room would have done.

data.sense: in a careless or untidy way

examples.text: The books were piled up all over the floor any old how.

data.sense: very old; ancient
to be behaving in the same bad way as before

examples.text: He had soon spent all the money and was up to his old tricks.

data.text: a chip off the old block
data.sense: a person who is very similar to their mother or father in the way that they look or behave
if you do something for old times’ sake, you do it because it is connected with something good that happened to you in the past
to dismiss somebody from their job; to end a relationship with somebody
an earlier period of time in your life or in history that is seen as better/worse than the present

examples.text: That was in the bad old days of rampant inflation.

data.sense: a great age

examples.text: She finally learned to drive at the grand old age of 70.

data.sense: a man who is respected in a particular profession that he has been involved in for a long time

examples.text: James Lovelock, the grand old man of environmental science

data.sense: to enjoy yourself very much
used to give an amount, a measurement, etc. using older or more traditional units that may be more familiar to some people

examples.text: The fish measured 29 centimetres (that's a foot in old money).

data.sense: money that is earned very easily, for something that needs little effort

examples.text: The job only took about an hour—it was money for old rope.

data.text: (there’s) no fool like an old fool
data.sense: an older person who behaves in a stupid way is worse than a younger person who does the same thing, because experience should have taught him or her not to do it
in or since past times

examples.text: in days of old
We know him of old (= we have known him for a long time).

data.sense: used by older men of the middle and upper classes as a friendly way of addressing another man

data.text: old enough to be somebody’s father/mother
data.sense: very much older than somebody (especially used to suggest that a romantic or sexual relationship between the two people is not appropriate)
old enough to behave in a more sensible way than you actually did

data.text: (have) an old head on young shoulders
data.sense: used to describe a young person who acts in a more sensible way than you would expect for a person of their age
what usually happens

examples.text: It's the same old story of a badly managed project with inadequate funding.

data.sense: an old idea or belief that people now know is not correct
an old-fashioned person who likes to do things as they were done in the past
an age that is considered to be very old

examples.text: He lived to the ripe old age of 91.

data.text: settle a score/accounts (with somebody) | settle an old score
data.sense: to hurt or punish somebody who has harmed or cheated you in the past

examples.text: ‘Who would do such a thing?’ ‘Maybe someone with an old score to settle.’
An embittered Charlotte is determined to settle accounts with Elizabeth.

data.text: (you can’t) teach an old dog new tricks
data.sense: (you cannot) successfully make people change their ideas, methods of work, etc., when they have had them for a long time

data.text: (as) tough as old boots | (as) tough as nails (informal)
data.sense: very strong and able to deal successfully with difficult conditions or situations

examples.text: She’s almost 90 but she’s still as tough as old boots.
